title-group.article-title: Socioeconomic deprivation and the epidemiology of carpal tunnel syndrome

contrib-group.aff: Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Queen Margaret Hospital, Dunfermline, UK

author-notes.corresp: Paul Jenkins, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Queen Margaret Hospital, Whitefield Road, Dunfermline, KY12 0SU, UK Email: paul@jenkinsnet.org.uk

permissions.copyright-statement: © The British Society for Surgery of the Hand 2011
permissions.copyright-holder: The British Society for Surgery of the Hand

abstract.p: Deprivation has been recognized as a major determinant of health and is associated with several musculoskeletal conditions. This study examines the effect of deprivation on the incidence of carpal tunnel syndrome using a regional prospective audit database. Over a 6 year period there were 1564 patients diagnosed with CTS with an annual incidence of 72/100,000 population. There was a significant difference in population incidence of CTS from the most deprived (81/100,000) to the least deprived (62/100,000) (p = 0.003). Functional impairment was higher in the most deprived group compared with the least (DASH 56 vs 48, p = 0.001). The most deprived group exhibited the greatest exposure to occupation vibration (42.7%), and had the greatest risk of bilateral disease (OR = 2.33, p < 0.001). We report an association between socioeconomic deprivation and carpal tunnel syndrome, with the disease being more likely to be bilateral and have a poorer DASH score in the most deprived patients.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is a common neuropathy, affecting the median nerve as it passes under the transverse carpal ligament (Phalen, 1966). The rate of surgical decompression in the UK is 43 to 74 per 100,000 per year (Palmer and Hanrahan, 1995). Previous epidemiological studies have used different diagnostic criteria and therefore the reported incidence varies from 0.125% to 1%, with a prevalence of up to 16% (Atroshi et al., 1999; de Krom et al., 1992; Ferry et al., 1998; Stevens et al., 1988; Tanaka et al., 1994). In a UK population, the mean male incidence was 67.2 per 100,000 and 139.4 in females with a female to male ration of 2.07 (Bland and Rudolfer, 2003).

CTS has been associated with trauma, diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, acromegaly, hypothyroidism and pregnancy (Becker et al., 2002; Lam and Thurston, 1998; Palmer et al., 2007). It has been associated with vibration and certain activities involving repetitive and forceful movements of the hands (Amadio, 1995; Bostrom et al., 1991; Hagberg et al., 1991; 1992; Palmer, et al., 2007).

The link between socioeconomic deprivation and disease was described in the Townsend Report (Townsend, 1974) and the Black Report (Black, 1980). Socioeconomic inequality has been associated with worse functional scores at time of hip and knee arthroplasty (Davis et al., 2008; Jenkins et al., 2009). It has been associated with the incidence of hand trauma (Horton et al., 2007) and the aetiology of Perthes disease (Kealey et al., 2000). Deprivation may also modulate access to healthcare (Milner et al., 2004; Yong et al., 2004).
The aim of this study was to report the epidemiology of CTS in a large UK population and to examine the influence of deprivation on incidence, symptom severity and associated risk factors.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: All patients diagnosed with CTS between November 2004 and May 2010 in a catchment population of over 360,000 were entered into a prospective audit database. Patients attended a regional hand service that was provided by the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery. No other treatment of carpal tunnel syndrome in secondary care was undertaken outside this department in our region, and there was no provision of regional hand services by a plastic surgical service. There is no private healthcare provider in the area. There were 1564 patients diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome over the study period. There were 612 patients with a unilateral presentation and there were 952 patients who had a bilateral simultaneous or staged presentation. There were therefore 2516 wrists considered in the study. For the purpose of comparisons, patients with bilateral presentations are considered as one patient, and only the function of the worst wrist is reported. This is to prevent the incorrect use of a t test for paired data.

Symptoms were recorded using a validated questionnaire (Kamath and Stothard, 2003). A clinical examination was performed and Phalen’s and Tinel’s test results recorded. Phalen’s test was performed by flexing the wrist for 60 seconds and noting pain and/or paraesthesia in the median nerve distribution. Tinel’s test was administered by lightly tapping over the median nerve at the wrist and observing for similar findings. A specialist hand therapist recorded the grip strength using a Jamar Hydraulic Hand Dynamometer (J00105, Lafayette Instruments, Lafayette, USA) and APB power was recorded. Nerve conduction studies were performed by a specialist technician using a Dantec Keypoint Portable Nerve Conduction/EMG machine (Dantec Dynamics, Bristol, UK), and reported by a consultant neurophysiologist. Results were classified as being negative, mild, moderate or severe, using criteria set by the neurophysiologist. Functional impairment was measured using the QuickDASH score patient reported outcome measure (PROM) (Gummesson et al., 2006; Mintken et al., 2009). A patient was diagnosed with CTS if they had symptoms of pain or paraesthesia in the median nerve distribution of the hand and one or more of the following: nerve conduction deficit, thenar muscle wasting or positive Tinel or Phalen signs.

The SIMD 2009 (Scottish Index of Multiple Deprivation) was used to quantify socioeconomic deprivation (Scottish Government, 2009). It combines 38 indicators across seven domains (income, employment, health, education, skills and training, housing, geographic access and crime). Patients were allocated to a datazone on the basis of their full postcode. Datazones were defined in 2004 and cover populations of 500 to 1000 people living in similar households with similar social characteristics. There are 6505 datazones in Scotland. Each datazone is allocated a score, and then allocated a quintile based on its relative deprivation within the Health Board area.

The NS-SEC (National Statistics Socio-economic Classification) was used to code occupations (Office of National Statistics, 2010). Patients were allocated to one of eight occupation types based on the self-coded variable (modern professional occupations, clerical and intermediate occupations, senior managers or administrators, technical and craft occupations, routine manual and service occupations, middle or junior managers, traditional professional occupations). It was also recorded if patients were chronically disabled or unemployed.

Mid-2009 population estimates were selected as the denominator used to calculate the over population incidence. The total health board population was 363,385 (General Registrar Office for Scotland, 2009).

sec.title: Statistical methods
sec.p: Annual incidences were calculated with 95% confidence intervals overall, for gender and by SIMD quintile. Chi squared tests were used to compare categorical data. Odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals were calculated for dichotomous outcomes. One way ANOVA (analysis of variance) tests were used to compare continuous parametric data across groups (QuickDASH score & Kamath Score) while the Kruskal Wallis test was used to compare APB strength across deprivation groups as it was measured using the ordinal MRC (Medical Research Council) scale. An alpha error rate of 0.05 was used to determine statistical significance and two-tailed p values reported.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The annual incidence in the Health Board Area was 72 per 100,000 per year (95% CI 63 to 80). CTS was more common in females (OR 1.9, 95 CI 1.5 to 2.5, p < 0.001) (Table 1). The mean age at presentation was 55.1 years (range 22 to 96, SD 13.5 years). The mean body mass index (BMI) was 29.5 kg/m2 (range 16 to 58, SD 6.1). There were 384 (24.6%) with a normal BMI, while 20 (1.3%) were underweight (BMI < 20), 546 (34.9%) were overweight (BMI 25–30), 316 (20.2%) were obese (BMI 30–35) and 244 (15.6%) were morbidly obese (BMI >35). Fifty-four patients had unrecorded body mass index. The mean duration of symptoms at first assessment was 48 months (range 2 to 552, SD 58.6).

caption.p: Incidence, occupation and recreation among patients with CTS

tr.td: Medicolegal claim for carpal tunnel syndrome (n, %)

fn.p: p value represents chi-squared comparison between male and female.

sec.p: The incidence of CTS varied significantly according to deprivation group (Table 2). The incidence of CTS in the most deprived group was 81/100,000 compared with 62/100,000 in the least deprived group (OR 1.3, 95% CI 1.1 to 1.6, p = 0.003). The incidence of CTS across the 396 geographical datazones ranged from 19 per 100,000 to 168 per 100,000, and showed a significant correlation with increasing deprivation (r = 0.21, p < 0.001).

caption.p: The effect of deprivation on incidence of carpal tunnel syndrome and nerve conduction studies

fn.p: p value represents comparison across all deprivation groups with ANOVA test or KW test (APB strength).

sec.p: The most common occupational group was routine manual and service occupations (n = 183, 11.8%) followed by semi-routine manual and service occupations (n = 175, 11.3%) (Table 1). There were 404 (26%) retired patients. In the retired group the most common occupational group had been semi-routine manual and service occupations (n = 91, 28%) followed by modern professional occupations (n = 76, 23%) and clerical and intermediate occupations (n = 60, 18.3%). There was a difference in gender in the clerical, technical and craft groups, routine manual and traditional professional groups (Table 1). There is a greater risk of bilateral disease in those in technical, craft (OR = 2.46, 95% CI 1.55 to 3.91, p < 0.001) and semi-routine manual and service occupations (OR = 1.8, 95% CI 1.28 to 2.56). Retired patients were more likely to have unilateral disease (OR 1.91, 95% CI 1.52 to 2.39, p < 0.001). There were 488 (31.2%) patients with self-reported exposure to vibrating tools. There was a significant difference in the reported incidence of occupational exposure to vibration between deprivation groups, with a rate of 42.7% in the most deprived group and 16.6% in the least (p < 0.001) (Table 2, Figure 1). There was a greater risk of bilateral disease in this group (OR = 2.33 95% CI 1.84 to 2.95, p < 0.001). Of the 360 patients with prior exposure to vibrating tools, 44 (12.2%) had made claims. Males were more likely to be exposed to vibrating tools (OR = 6.9, 95% CI 5.4 to 8.7, p < 0.001) (Table 1).

caption.p: Incidence of CTS (±95% CI) and occupational vibration exposure (% of total) versus socioeconomic deprivation category.

sec.p: The preoperative DASH score was highest in the most deprived group (p < 0.001). There were no differences in the nerve conduction test outcomes between deprivation groups. Bilateral presentation was more common in more deprived groups (n = 116, 53.5%) compared with the least (n = 97, 33.9%) (p = 0.002) (Table 2).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study demonstrates an association between deprivation and the incidence of carpal tunnel syndrome. It also demonstrates a wide variation in incidence according to geographical area. Patients in more deprived areas tended to have a higher incidence of exposure to occupational vibration, and this was associated with an increased tendency towards bilateral disease with poorer function and had more medicolegal claims.

The results presented here are comparable to previous studies (Nordstrom et al., 1998; Papanicolaou et al., 2001; Stevens et al., 1988). These have shown an incidence of 0.125% to 1% and prevalence of 2.7% to 16% (Atroshi et al., 1999; de Krom et al., 1992; Stevens et al., 1988; Tanaka et al., 1994) with the highest incidence in females in their sixth decade (Bland and Rudolfer, 2003; Lam and Thurston, 1998). The age at presentation in females and males shows a unimodal distribution in agreement with Phalen’s original report (Phalen, 1966). There have been studies reporting a different pattern such as the Rochester cohort with a positive correlation with age in men only (Stevens et al., 1988) and the Ontario data showing a bimodal distribution in females with a second peak in the ninth decade (Liss et al., 1992).

The impact of occupation and particular hand movements has been difficult to assess. It was first suggested as an occupational disease in 1947 (Brain et al., 1947). A large number of studies have attempted to examine this but they are mostly retrospective and it is difficult to control for variations within activities. Many studies rely on self-reported activity levels. Manual work and exposure to vibration have been identified as predisposing factors (Atroshi et al., 1999; Hagberg et al., 1991; Wieslander et al., 1989). These findings have been confirmed by two separate systematic reviews (Hagberg et al., 1992; Palmer et al., 2007). Basic scientific studies have shown increases in carpal tunnel pressures during flexion and extension (Werner et al., 1986), with the highest occurring with forearm supination and full flexion. A prospective study with independent job analysis showed an odds ratio of 2.7 for low force jobs, and 15.5 for high force jobs (Silverstein et al., 1987). Nerve conduction impairment has been noted to be associated with high repetition and force (Stetson et al., 1993) while other studies have refuted this (Nathan et al., 2005; Schottland et al., 1991). Although CTS has previously been linked with repetitive and high force wrist movements, the original study describing this has problems with diagnosis and self-reported measures of occupational exposure (Silverstein et al., 1987). In the UK CTS is described an occupation disease only when the occupation has involved the use of vibratory tools (Palmer et al., 2007). Exposure to vibratory tools showed a risk of 2–3.3 in those using them (Nordstrom et al., 1997; Wieslander et al., 1989).

Socioeconomic deprivation is associated with occupation, but encompasses a variety of other measures of social exclusion. As such it is associated with a variety of musculoskeletal disorders (Davis et al., 2008; Dixon et al., 2004; Jenkins et al., 2009; Milner et al., 2004). In the realm of hand trauma, deprivation has been associated with increased presentations to a trauma unit (Horton et al., 2007). In this population increasing deprivation is associated with an increased incidence of carpal tunnel syndrome. When CTS presents in more deprived patients, they also report greater functional impairment. Socioeconomic deprivation reflects occupation, general health and access to health care (Hacker and Stanistreet, 2004). Our observations may reflect a reluctance in more deprived groups to seek attention and implement preventative measures at an earlier stage in the disease process. There may also be other drivers of these observations such as ongoing medicolegal action pertaining to occupational exposure to vibration. A distinction is necessary between causation and association. Although associated with socioeconomic deprivation, we cannot assume that CTS results directly from it, and it may serve as indicator of an underlying common cause such as variation in comorbidity or activity levels.

This study is powerful due to the large number of patients included. It encompasses all patients diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome in a Health Board Area. There is a dedicated hand team comprised of a surgeon, two specialist nurses, and two hand therapists. We have used a methodology of categorizing deprivation that has been validated in other studies of orthopaedic conditions. The limitations of the study include possibility that patients at the fringes of the health board area may undergo treatment in a different unit. We are unable to take account of this but assume it is balanced by similar migration into our area in these regions (20 patients underwent treatment in our unit over the study period from other health board areas). Patients may also receive treatment completely in the community from the general practitioner, although any request for nerve conduction testing must be routed through our hand service. No patients attending our clinic have previously received an injection in the community from their general practitioner. We have used a self-reported occupational grading. There is also a potential for subjectivity in the reporting of nerve conduction studies as the neurophysiologists reported a clinical impression that took into account the battery of neurophysiological tests they undertook.

In conclusion, there is an association between deprivation, geography and carpal tunnel syndrome. Further research should explore the nature of these associations and identify which components of social and economic deprivation have the greatest impact on possible aetiology. Future studies should also re-examine causal relationships between the intensity and performance of manual tasks and the subsequent risk of developing CTS. Identification of particular causal relationships may lead to greater precision in its primary prevention.

ack.p: Mr Gunvant Patel – Associate Specialist Orthopaedic Surgeon, Elaine Graham – Specialist Nurse, Lynn Gordon – Specialist Nurse.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Conflict of interests
sec.p: None declared.
